query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Dal centro al cerchio, e sì dal cerchio al centro 2 movesi l’acqua in un ritondo vaso, 3 secondo ch’è percosso fuori o dentro:
4 ne la mia mente fé sùbito caso 5 questo ch’io dico, sì come si tacque 6 la glorïosa vita di Tommaso,
7 per la similitudine che nacque 8 del suo parlare e di quel di Beatrice, 9 a cui sì cominciar, dopo lui, piacque:
10 «A costui fa mestieri, e nol vi dice 11 né con la voce né pensando ancora, 12 d’un altro vero andare a la radice.
query.result:
**English:**
1 From the center to the rim, and likewise from the rim to the center, 2 the water moves in a round vessel, 3 according to whether it is struck from outside or from within:
4 in my mind this that I say suddenly occurred 5 as soon as the glorious life of Thomas fell silent,
6 because of the similarity that arose 7 between his speech and that of Beatrice, 8 to whom it pleased to begin, after him, thus:
9 "This man has need, and he does not tell you 10 either with his voice or yet by thinking, 11 to go to the root of another truth.
**Old English:**
1 Fram ðæm middele to ðæm ytemestan, and eac fram ðæm ytemestan to ðæm middele, 2 styreð ðæt wæter on anum ymbhwyrfede fæte, 3 æfter ðæm ðe hit bið utan oððe innan astyred:
4 on minum mode wearð ðæt ða sona geðuht 5 ðæt ic ðis secge, swa swa ða geswac 6 ðæs mæran Thomas lifes stefn,
7 ðurh ða gelicnesse ðe wearð acenned 8 of his spræce and of ðære Beatricean, 9 ðære hit licode ða æfter him ðus onginnan:
10 "Ðisum is neod, and he hit eow ne sægð 11 ne ðurh stefne ne ðurh ðenceað giet, 12 ðæt he to ðære wyrtruman oðres soðes fare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Come, da più letizia pinti e tratti, 20 a la fïata quei che vanno a rota 21 levan la voce e rallegrano li atti,
22 così, a l’orazion pronta e divota, 23 li santi cerchi mostrar nova gioia 24 nel torneare e ne la mira nota.
query.result:
**English:**
19 As those who are painted and drawn by greater joy, 20 when they go round in a ring, 21 raise their voices and gladden their movements,
22 so, ready and devout in prayer, 23 the holy circles showed new joy 24 in their circling and in the wonderful song.
**Old English:**
19 Swa ða ðe beoð mid maran blisse geglengede and getogene, 20 ðonne hi onhring rincum ryneð, 21 heora stefna styriað and heora wlite wlitigað,
22 swa ða halgan heapas heora heortan lufan 23 on ðam weorðfullan wuldordreame 24 on ðam fægeran gefean fæstnodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Qual si lamenta perché qui si moia 26 per viver colà sù, non vide quive 27 lo refrigerio de l’etterna ploia.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Who laments because he dies here 26 in order to live up there, did not see here 27 the refreshment of the eternal rain.
**Old English:**
25 Hwa ðe wepeð forðæm ðe he her swelteð 26 ðurh ðæt ðe he mæg lybban ðær ufan, ne geseah he her 27 ðone gefean ðære ecæn rine.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Quell’ uno e due e tre che sempre vive 29 e regna sempre in tre e ’n due e ’n uno, 30 non circunscritto, e tutto circunscrive,
31 tre volte era cantato da ciascuno 32 di quelli spirti con tal melodia, 33 ch’ad ogne merto saria giusto muno.
query.result:
**English:**
28 That One and Two and Three who always lives 29 and reigns always in three and two and one, 30 not circumscribed, and circumscribes all,
31 was sung three times by each 32 of those spirits with such melody, 33 that to every merit it would be a just reward.
**Old English:**
28 Se ðæt an and ðæt twægen and ðæt ðreo ðe symle lyfað 29 and rixað symle on ðrim and on twam and on anum, 30 unbesegen and eall ymbesegð,
31 ðreo siðum wæs gesungen fram ælcum 32 ðæra gasta mid swylcum gomenum, 33 ðæt æghwylcum men wære med ryht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E io udi’ ne la luce più dia 35 del minor cerchio una voce modesta, 36 forse qual fu da l’angelo a Maria,
37 risponder: «Quanto fia lunga la festa 38 di paradiso, tanto il nostro amore 39 si raggerà dintorno cotal vesta.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And I heard in the brighter light 35 of the smaller circle a modest voice, 36 perhaps like that of the angel to Mary,
37 answering: "As long as the feast 38 of paradise shall last, so long our love 39 shall radiate around such a garment."
**Old English:**
34 And ic gehyrde on ðæm leohte ðæs lytlan hweorfes 35 ænne hlysendlican stefn, 36 efne swylce wæs ðæs engles to Marian,
37 andswariende: "Swa lange swa ðæs heofonlican gefean 38 wunað, swa lange ure lufu 39 ymb ðis gegyrle scinð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 La sua chiarezza séguita l’ardore; 41 l’ardor la visïone, e quella è tanta, 42 quant’ ha di grazia sovra suo valore.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Its brightness follows the ardor; 41 the ardor, the vision; and that is as great 42 as the grace that exceeds its worth.
**Old English:**
40 Hire beorhtnes folgað ðæm bryne; 41 se bryne ðære gesyhðe, and seo is swilce, 42 swa micel swa ðære gife ðe hire weorðscipe oferstíhð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Tanto mi parver sùbiti e accorti 62 e l’uno e l’altro coro a dicer «Amme!», 63 che ben mostrar disio d’i corpi morti:
64 forse non pur per lor, ma per le mamme, 65 per li padri e per li altri che fuor cari 66 anzi che fosser sempiterne fiamme.
query.result:
**English:**
61 So sudden and eager both choirs seemed to me 62 to say "Amen!", the one and the other, 63 that they clearly showed their desire for their mortal bodies:
64 perhaps not only for themselves, but for their mothers, 65 for their fathers and for the others who were dear to them 66 before they became eternal flames.
**Old English:**
61 Swa ðuhte me ða ðreatas ðearle georne 62 and ða oðre ðe ðær wæron to secganne "Amen!", 63 ðæt hi wel cyðdon ðæt hi ðara deadra lichamanna wilnedon:
64 næfre ðeah for ðam anum, ac for ðam mæððum, 65 for ðam fæderum and for ðam oðrum ðe him leofe wæron 66 ær ðam ðe hi ða synfullan fyras wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Ed ecco intorno, di chiarezza pari, 68 nascere un lustro sopra quel che v’era, 69 per guisa d’orizzonte che rischiari.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And behold, all around, with equal brightness, 68 a light was born above what was there, 69 in the manner of a horizon that grows light.
**Old English:**
67 And eallunga ymbe, ðære beorhtnesse gelice, 68 weard geboren leoma ofer ðam ðe ðær wæs, 69 on ðære wisan ðæs horizontis ðe leoht bið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E sì come al salir di prima sera 71 comincian per lo ciel nove parvenze, 72 sì che la vista pare e non par vera,
73 parvemi lì novelle sussistenze 74 cominciare a vedere, e fare un giro 75 di fuor da l’altre due circunferenze.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And just as at the approach of evening 71 new stars begin to appear in the sky, 72 so that the sight seems real and yet not real,
73 it seemed to me that new substances 74 began to appear there, and to make a circle 75 outside the other two circumferences.
**Old English:**
70 And swa swa æt ðæs æfensynges upgange 71 onginnað ðurh ðone rodor niwe steorran, 72 swa ðæt ðæt gesihð ðinceð and nis soð,
73 ðuhte me ðær niwe gesceaftas 74 onginnan to gesienne, and wyrcan ymbegang 75 utan ða oðre twegen ymbhwyrftas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Oh vero sfavillar del Santo Spiro! 77 come si fece sùbito e candente 78 a li occhi miei che, vinti, nol soffriro!
79 Ma Bëatrice sì bella e ridente 80 mi si mostrò, che tra quelle vedute 81 si vuol lasciar che non seguir la mente.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Oh true sparkling of the Holy Spirit! 77 How suddenly and brightly it became 78 to my eyes, which, overcome, could not bear it!
79 But Beatrice, so beautiful and smiling, 80 appeared to me, that among those visions 81 one must allow the mind not to follow.
**Old English:**
76 Eala, soðfæst scinung ðæs Halgan Gastes! 77 Hu ðu ðe ðær ðone hrade and ðone hatan 78 minum gesyhðe æteowdest, ðe ðe ða oferwunnen ne mihte!
79 Ac ða ðu, Beatrice, ðu ða swa fæger and ðu ða swa blide 80 ðu ðe ðær ða ætywdes ðæt ðara gesyhða 81 man sceal ða forlætan ðe ða se hyge ne mæg fyligean.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Quindi ripreser li occhi miei virtute 83 a rilevarsi; e vidimi translato 84 sol con mia donna in più alta salute.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Then my eyes regained their strength 83 to rise up; and I saw myself translated 84 with my lady alone to a higher salvation.
**Old English:**
82 ða eft minra eagna gesihð geswutelode 83 ðæt ic ðær ðurh ðone dimman wudu 84 mid minre ðeowene ðurh ðone deopan dal 85 ðurh ðone wudu wæs on weg broht 86 ðurh ðone fægeran feld ðær ða fægran wæron 87 ða ðe ðurh ðone halgan hyht ða heofonlican 88 ðurh ða gastlican gesihðe ða gleawan gesawon.
(Note: This is a poetic translation of the passage into Old English, as there is no direct equivalent to Dante's terza rima in Old English poetry.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ben m’accors’ io ch’io era più levato, 86 per l’affocato riso de la stella, 87 che mi parea più roggio che l’usato.
query.result:
**English:**
85 I realized that I had risen higher, 86 because of the fiery glow of the star, 87 which seemed redder to me than usual.
**Old English:**
85 Ic ða oncneow ðæt ic wæs hlihhor ahafen, 86 ðurh ðæs steorran fyrenan leoman, 87 ðe me ðuhte readra ðonne gewunelic.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Con tutto ’l core e con quella favella 89 ch’è una in tutti, a Dio feci olocausto, 90 qual conveniesi a la grazia novella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 With all my heart and with that speech 89 which is one in all, I made a burnt offering to God, 90 as is fitting for the new grace.
**Old English:**
88 Mid ealre heortan and mid ðære spræce 89 ðe is an eallum, Gode ic offrode, 90 swa swa gedafenað ðære niwan gife.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Di corno in corno e tra la cima e ’l basso 110 si movien lumi, scintillando forte 111 nel congiugnersi insieme e nel trapasso:
112 così si veggion qui diritte e torte, 113 veloci e tarde, rinovando vista, 114 le minuzie d’i corpi, lunghe e corte,
115 moversi per lo raggio onde si lista 116 talvolta l’ombra che, per sua difesa, 117 la gente con ingegno e arte acquista.
query.result:
**English:**
109 From horn to horn and between the summit and the base, 110 lights were moving, sparkling brightly 111 as they came together and passed by:
112 thus one sees here, straight and crooked, 113 fast and slow, renewing their appearance, 114 the tiny particles of bodies, long and short,
115 moving through the beam of light that sometimes outlines 116 the shadow that people, with skill and art, 117 acquire for their protection.
**Old English:**
109 Of horn in horn and between the top and the bottom 110 lights moved, shining brightly 111 in the joining together and in the passing by:
112 thus one sees here straight and crooked, 113 fast and slow, renewing their appearance, 114 the tiny particles of bodies, long and short,
115 moving through the beam of light that sometimes outlines 116 the shadow that people, with skill and art, 117 acquire for their protection.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 E come giga e arpa, in tempra tesa 119 di molte corde, fa dolce tintinno 120 a tal da cui la nota non è intesa,
121 così da’ lumi che lì m’apparinno 122 s’accogliea per la croce una melode 123 che mi rapiva, sanza intender l’inno.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And like a zither and a harp, tightly strung 119 with many strings, makes a sweet tinkling sound 120 to one who does not understand the notes,
121 so from the lights that appeared to me there 122 a melody gathered around the cross 123 that enraptured me, without my understanding the hymn.
**Old English:**
118 And swa gigan and hearpan, on strengum strengum, 119 manigra strenga, wynsumne hleopor 120 ðam ðe ðara strenga ne cunne,
121 swa ðara leohta ðe ðær me lihton 122 ymb ða rode gesamnod was swylce strenga 123 ðe me gewundrod hæfde, ðeah ðe ic ðone lofsang ne cuðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Ben m’accors’ io ch’elli era d’alte lode, 125 però ch’a me venìa «Resurgi» e «Vinci» 126 come a colui che non intende e ode.
query.result:
**English:**
124 I understood well that he was worthy of high praise, 125 because he said to me "Arise" and "Conquer" 126 like one who does not understand but hears.
**Old English:**
124 Ic wel ongeat ðæt he wæs lof-wyðe, 125 forðæm he cwæð to me "Aris" and "Vincas" 126 swa swa ðam ðe ne ongieteð ac gehýreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ïo m’innamorava tanto quinci, 128 che ’nfino a lì non fu alcuna cosa 129 che mi legasse con sì dolci vinci.
query.result:
**English:**
127 I was falling in love so much there, 128 that up to that point there was nothing 129 that bound me with such sweet bonds.
**Old English:**
127 Ic me onlufode ðær swa swiðe, 128 ðæt oð ðone sið ne wæs ænig ðing 129 ðe me bunde mid swilcum beágum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Forse la mia parola par troppo osa, 131 posponendo il piacer de li occhi belli, 132 ne’ quai mirando mio disio ha posa;
133 ma chi s’avvede che i vivi suggelli 134 d’ogne bellezza più fanno più suso, 135 e ch’io non m’era lì rivolto a quelli,
136 escusar puommi di quel ch’io m’accuso 137 per escusarmi, e vedermi dir vero: 138 ché ’l piacer santo non è qui dischiuso,
139 perché si fa, montando, più sincero.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Perhaps my words seem too bold, 131 since I put aside the pleasure of those beautiful eyes, 132 in gazing upon which my desire finds repose;
133 but whoever realizes that the living seals 134 of every beauty make more beauty above, 135 and that I had not turned to those there,
136 can excuse me for what I accuse myself of 137 in order to excuse myself and see me tell the truth: 138 for holy pleasure is not revealed here,
139 because it becomes purer as one ascends.
**Old English:**
130 Witod me ðin word ðinceð to ðriste, 131 ðæt ic ðæs wlitegan leoman lufu 132 forsacan sceolde, ðær min sefa wunað;
133 ac ða ðe ða lyfigendan insegl 134 æghwylces fægernysse freolicor wyrcað, 135 and ðæt ic ðær to ðam ne wende,
136 mæg ðæt me forgifan ðæs ðe ic me sylfne wrige, 137 ðæt ic me sylfne wrigen hæbbe, and ðæt ic soð sprecan mæge: 138 forðæm ðe ðæt halige gefea ðær nis awrigen,
139 forðæm ðe hit wyrð clænre ðurh ðæt stigende.
